revision.text: [[File:Colorful dreidels2.JPG|thumb|250px|Dreidels for sale at [[Mahane Yehuda Market]] in [[Jerusalem]]]] A '''dreidel''' ({{lang-yi|דרײדל}} ''dreydl'' plural: ''dreydlekh'',''[[Dreydlekh]]'' is also a term in [[klezmer]] music {{lang-he-n|סביבון}} ''sevivon'') is a four-sided [[spinning top]], played with during the [[Jewish holiday]] of [[Hanukkah]]. The dreidel is a Jewish variant on the [[teetotum]], a gambling toy found in many European cultures. Each side of the dreidel bears a letter of the Hebrew alphabet: {{Hebrew|נ}} ([[Nun (letter)|Nun]]), {{Hebrew|ג}} ([[Gimel (letter)|Gimel]]), {{Hebrew|ה}} ([[He (letter)|Hei]]), {{Hebrew|ש}} ([[Shin (letter)|Shin]]), which together form the acronym for "{{Hebrew|'''נ'''ס '''ג'''דול '''ה'''יה '''ש'''ם}}" ('''N'''es '''G'''adol '''H'''ayah '''Sh'''am – "a great miracle happened '''th'''ere"). These letters were originally a mnemonic for the rules of a gambling game played with a dreidel: Nun stands for the [[Yiddish]] word ''nisht'' ("nothing"), Hei stands for ''halb'' ("half"), Gimel for ''gants'' ("all"), and Shin for ''shtel ayn'' ("put in"). In [[Israel]], the fourth side of most dreidels is inscribed with the letter {{Hebrew|פ}} ([[Pe (letter)|Pei]]) instead, rendering the acronym, {{Hebrew|'''נ'''ס '''ג'''דול '''ה'''יה '''פ'''ה}}, '''''N'''es '''G'''adol '''H'''ayah '''P'''oh''—"A great miracle happened '''h'''ere", referring to the miracle occurring in the Land of Israel. ==Origins== [[Image:Dreidel 001.jpg|thumb|125px|right|Wooden dreidel]] According to most scholars, the dreidel developed from an Irish or English top introduced into Germany known as a ''{{lang|la|[[teetotum]]}}'',{{cite news|last1=Kutzik|first1=Jordan|title=Our Favorite Hanukkah Toy Was Actually a Non-Jewish Irish Gambling Game|url=https://forward.com/culture/326379/the-true-history-of-the-dreidel/|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171215061644/https://forward.com/culture/326379/the-true-history-of-the-dreidel/|archivedate=2017-12-15|df=}}{{cite web|last1=Rabinowitz|first1=Dan|title=Chanukah Customs and sources|url=http://seforim.blogspot.co.uk/2005/12/chanukah-customs-and-sources.html|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171222051048/http://seforim.blogspot.co.uk/2005/12/chanukah-customs-and-sources.html|archivedate=2017-12-22|df=}}{{cite news|last1=Rosenberg|first1=Anat|title=The Weird Ancient History of the Dreidel|url=https://www.haaretz.com/jewish/1.631316|accessdate=19 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171219045509/https://www.haaretz.com/jewish/1.631316|archivedate=19 December 2017|df=}}{{cite web|last1=Golinkin|first1=David|title=The Surprising Origin of the Dreidel |url=https://www.myjewishlearning.com/article/the-origin-of-the-dreidel|work=myjewishlearning.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171213084023/https://www.myjewishlearning.com/article/the-origin-of-the-dreidel/|archivedate=2017-12-13|df=}}{{cite web|last1=Pfeffer|first1=Rabbi Yehoshua|title=The Chanukah Dreidel and its Halachos|url=http://dinonline.org/2015/12/07/the-chanukah-dreidel-and-its-halachos|website=dinonline.org|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171222105226/http://dinonline.org/2015/12/07/the-chanukah-dreidel-and-its-halachos/|archivedate=2017-12-22|df=}} which was popular around Christmastime and dates back to ancient Greek and Roman times. The teetotum was inscribed with letters denoting the Latin words for “nothing,” “half,” “everything” and “put in.” In German this came to be called a ''{{lang|de|trendel}}'', with German letters for the same concepts. Adapted to the Hebrew alphabet when Jews adopted the game, these letters were replaced by [[Shin (letter)|shin]] (=''{{lang|yi-Latn|shtel arayn}}'', put in); [[Nun (letter)|nun]] (=''{{lang|yi-Latn|nit}}'', not, i.e., nothing); [[gimel]] (=''{{lang|yi-Latn|gants}}'', whole/everything); and [[He (letter)|he]] (=''{{lang|yi-Latn|halb}}'', half). The letters served as a means to recalling the rules of the game. This theory states that when the game spread to Jewish communities unfamiliar with Yiddish, the denotations of the Hebrew letters were not understood. As a result, there arose Jewish traditions to explain their assumed meaning. However, in Judaism there are often multiple explanations developed for words. Some claimed the 4 letters cyphered Babylon, Persia, Greece and the Roman Empire, the four ancient empires that tried to destroy Israel; a [[gematriya]] reading yielded the number 358, identical to the value of the 4 letters used for Moshiach (''[[Messiah]]''). A third popular conjecture had it that the letters abbreviated the words "''{{lang|he-Latn|nes gadol haya sham}}''" (a great miracle happened there), an idea that became attached to dreidels when the game entered into Hanukkah festivities.Jordan Kutzik, [http://forward.com/culture/yiddish-culture/326379/the-true-history-of-the-dreidel/?attribution=home-hero-item-text-3 'The True History of the Dreidel,] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304060116/http://forward.com/culture/yiddish-culture/326379/the-true-history-of-the-dreidel/?attribution=home-hero-item-text-3 |date=2016-03-04 }}' [[The Forward]] December 9, 2015 According to a tradition first documented in 1890,{{cite web|title=Dreidel Drama|url=http://cdn.yutorah.org/_materials/Source_sheets-513377.pdf|website=yutorah.org|publisher=Yeshiva University}}{{cite book|last1=הירשוביץ|first1=אברהם אליעזר בן איזיק|title=אוצר כל מנהגי ישרון|date=1918|location=http://hebrewbooks.org/pdfpager.aspx?req=2604&st=&pgnum=95|page=57}}{{cite book|last1=צינר|first1=גבריאל|title=הלכות חנוכה - נטעי גבריאל|page=306}} the game was developed by Jews who illegally studied the [[Torah]] in seclusion as they hid, sometimes in caves, from the [[Seleucid Empire|Seleucids]] under [[Antiochus IV]]. At the first sign of Seleucids approaching, their [[Sefer Torah|Torah scrolls]] would be concealed and be replaced by dreidels.{{cite web | url=http://www.jewfaq.org/holiday7.htm | title=Chanukkah | accessdate=27 November 2015 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160107165729/http://www.jewfaq.org/holiday7.htm | archivedate=7 January 2016 | df= }}{{cite web | url=http://www.chabad.org/holidays/chanukah/article_cdo/aid/603267/jewish/What-is-a-Dreidel.htm | title=What is a Dreidel? | accessdate=27 November 2015 | author=Benjaminson, Chani | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151127212013/http://www.chabad.org/holidays/chanukah/article_cdo/aid/603267/jewish/What-is-a-Dreidel.htm | archivedate=27 November 2015 | df= }} The variant names ''{{lang|yi-Latn|goyrl}}'' (destiny) and ''{{lang|yi-Latn|varfl}}'' (a little throw) were also current in Yiddish until [[the Holocaust]]. In the wake of Zionism, the dreidel was renamed ''{{lang|he-Latn|sevivon}}'' in modern Hebrew, and the letters altered, with ''shin'' generally replaced by [[pe (letter)|pe]]. This yields the reading ''{{lang|he-Latn|nes gadol haya po}}'' (a great miracle happened ''here''.') ==Etymology== The [[Yiddish]] word ''{{lang|yi-Latn|dreydl}}'' comes from the word ''{{lang|yi-Latn|dreyen}}'' ("to turn", compare to ''{{lang|de|drehen}}'', meaning the same in German). The [[Hebrew]] word ''{{lang|he-Latn|sevivon}}'' comes from the [[Semitic root]] "[[wikt:סיבוב|SBB]]" ("to turn") and was invented by [[Itamar Ben-Avi]] (the son of [[Eliezer Ben-Yehuda]]) when he was 5 years old. [[Hayyim Nahman Bialik]] used a different word, "kirkar" (from the root "KRKR" – "to spin"), in his poems,{{cite web |url=http://benyehuda.org/bialik/bia_chds54.html |title=Ben Yehuda organization: Bialik |publisher=Benyehuda.org |date= |accessdate=2011-12-23 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720050522/http://benyehuda.org/bialik/bia_chds54.html |archivedate=2011-07-20 |df= }} but it was not adopted into spoken Hebrew. In the lexicon of [[Ashkenazi Jews]] from [[Udmurtia]] and [[Tatarstan]] the local historian A.V. Altyntsev was fixed several other appellations of a dreidel such as "volchok", "khanuke-volchok", "fargl", "varfl", "dzihe" and "zabavke".Altyntsev A.V., "The Concept of Love in Ashkenazim of Udmurtia and Tatarstan", Nauka Udmurtii. 2013. № 4 (66), p. 130. (Алтынцев А.В., [http://snioo.ru/images/stories/nu-print/nu4662013.pdf "Чувство любви в понимании евреев-ашкенази Удмуртии и Татарстана".] Наука Удмуртии. 2013. №4. С. 130: Комментарии.) {{ru icon}} ==Symbolism== Some rabbis ascribe symbolic significance to the markings on the dreidel. One commentary, for example, connects the four letters with the four nations to which the House of Judah was historically subject—[[Babylonia]], [[Persia]], [[Seleucid Empire]] and [[Ancient Rome|Rome]].{{cite web |last=Yaakov |first=Rabbi |url=http://www.ohr.org.il/yhiy/article.php/1309 |title=Secret of the Dreidel |publisher=Ohr.org.il |date= |accessdate=2011-12-23 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516210032/http://www.ohr.org.il/yhiy/article.php/1309 |archivedate=2008-05-16 |df= }} While not mandated (a [[mitzvah]]) for Hanukkah (the only traditional ''{{lang|he-Latn|mitzvot}}'' are lighting candles and saying the full [[hallel]]), spinning the dreidel is a traditional game played during the holiday.[http://www.ny1.com/content/top_stories/55918/brooklyn-man-wins-dreidel-spinning-contest Brooklyn Man Wins Dreidel Spinning Contest] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523082110/http://www.ny1.com/content/top_stories/55918/brooklyn-man-wins-dreidel-spinning-contest |date=May 23, 2013 }} ==Rules of the game== Each player begins with an equal number of game pieces (usually 10–15). The game pieces can be any object, such as [[chocolate gelt]], pennies, raisins, etc. *To start the game, every participant puts one game piece into the center "pot". Every player also puts one piece into the pot at the end of every player's turn. *Each player spins the dreidel once during their turn. Depending on which side is facing up when it stops spinning, the player whose turn it is gives or takes game pieces from the pot: **If {{Hebrew|נ}} (''nun'') is facing up, the player does nothing. **If {{Hebrew|ג}} (''gimel'') is facing up, the player gets everything in the pot. **If {{Hebrew|ה}} (''hei'') is facing up, the player gets half of the pieces in the pot. If there are an odd number of pieces in the pot, the player takes the half the pot rounded up to the nearest whole number. **If {{Hebrew|ש}} (''shin'') or {{Hebrew|פ}} (''pe'') is facing up, the player adds one of their game pieces to the pot (sometimes accompanied by the chant "Shin, Shin, put one in"{{cite book|last=LeBon|first=Marilee|title=The complete idiot's guide to holiday crafts|year=2001|pages=73|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3qPlFK_yGckC&q=%22shin+put+one+in%22+dreidel&dq=%22shin+put+one+in%22+dreidel|isbn=9780028642000}}). In some game versions a Shin results in adding three game pieces to the pot (one for each stem of the Shin). *If the player is out of pieces, they are either "out" or may ask another player for a "loan".{{cite web |url=http://www.myjewishlearning.com/holidays/Jewish_Holidays/Hanukkah/At_Home/Dreidel/How_To_Play.shtml |title=How to Play |publisher=Myjewishlearning.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-23 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111209035018/http://www.myjewishlearning.com/holidays/Jewish_Holidays/Hanukkah/At_Home/Dreidel/How_To_Play.shtml |archivedate=2011-12-09 |df= }} These rules are comparable to the rules for a classic four-sided [[teetotum]], where the letters A, D, N and T form a [[mnemonic]] for the rules of the game, ''{{lang|la|aufer}}'' (take), ''{{lang|la|depone}}'' (put), ''{{lang|la|nihil}}'' (nothing), and ''{{lang|la|totum}}'' (all). Similarly, the Hebrew letters on a dreidel may be taken as a mnemonic for the game rules in Yiddish. Occasionally, in the United States, the Hebrew letters on the dreidel form an English-language mnemonic about the rules: Hay or "H" for "half;" Gimel or "G" for "get all;" Nun or "N" for "nothing;" and Shin or "S" for "share". Thomas Robinson and Sujith Vijay have shown that the expected number of spins in a game of dreidel is '''O(n2)''', where n is the number of game pieces each player begins with. The implied constant depends on the number of players.{{cite journal |last1=Robinson|first1=Thomas|last2=Vijay|first2=Sujith|title=Dreidel Lasts O(n2) spins|doi=10.1016/j.aam.2005.05.004|volume=36|journal=Advances in Applied Mathematics|pages=85–94}} ==Collections== Childhood enjoyment of dreidels has led to interest in collecting them in adulthood.{{cite web |url=http://www.forward.com/articles/133206/ |title=Oh Dreidel, Dreidel, Dreidel: A favorite holiday pastime takes center table |publisher=Forward.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-23 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606012655/http://www.forward.com/articles/133206/ |archivedate=2011-06-06 |df= }} Jewish institutions such as the [[Spertus Institute for Jewish Learning and Leadership]], Yeshiva University Museum and [[Congregation Emanu-El of New York|Temple Emanu-El]] in New York, house dreidel collections, as do museums such as the Spinning Top and Yo-Yo Museum in Burlington, Wisconsin. ==Tournaments== Dreidel is now a spoof competitive sport in North America. Major League Dreidel (MLD), founded in New York City in 2007, hosts dreidel tournaments during the holiday of Hanukkah. In MLD tournaments the player with the longest time of spin (TOS) is the winner. MLD is played on a Spinagogue, the official spinning stadium of Major League Dreidel. Pamskee was the 2007 MLD Champion. Virtual Dreidel was the 2008 MLD Champion.{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=98610612 |title=No Gelt, No Glory: A Dreidel Champion Is Crowned |publisher=Npr.org |date= |accessdate=2011-12-23 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120106215518/http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=98610612 |archivedate=2012-01-06 |df= }} In 2009, Major League Dreidel launched a game version of the Spinagogue.{{cite web |url=http://www.moderntribe.com/judaica/hanukkah/spinagogue/spinagogue |title=Spinagogue |publisher=Moderntribe.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100301170656/http://www.moderntribe.com/judaica/hanukkah/spinagogue/spinagogue |archivedate=2010-03-01 |df= }} In 2009, ''[[Good Morning America]]'' published a story on Dreidel Renaissance reporting on the rising popularity of the dreidel.{{cite web |last=Milberger |first=Michael |url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/Weekend/dreidel-invented-dreidel-games-generation/story?id=9315727 |title=Dreidel Games Generation |publisher=Abcnews.go.com |date=2009-12-12 |accessdate=2011-12-23 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120125063212/http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/Weekend/dreidel-invented-dreidel-games-generation/story?id=9315727 |archivedate=2012-01-25 |df= }} Dreidel games that have come out on the market since 2007 include No Limit Texas Dreidel,{{cite web |url=http://www.texasdreidel.com |title=No Limit Texas Dreidel |publisher=Texasdreidel.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-23 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111208085031/http://texasdreidel.com/ |archivedate=2011-12-08 |df= }} a cross between traditional dreidel and [[Texas Hold'em]] poker, invented by a [[Judaica]] company called ModernTribe.{{cite web|url=http://www.moderntribe.com|title=Judaica & Jewish Gifts for Modern Jewish Living|author=|date=|website=ModernTribe|accessdate=27 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180407223603/https://moderntribe.com/|archivedate=7 April 2018|df=}} Other new dreidel games include Staccabees{{cite web |url=http://www.staccabees.com/ |title=Staccabees |publisher=Staccabees |date= |accessdate=2011-12-23 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111219192600/http://www.staccabees.com/ |archivedate=2011-12-19 |df= }} and Maccabees.{{cite web |url=http://www.jweekly.com/article/full/40728/battle-of-the-bees-two-games-put-a-new-spin-on-traditional-dreidel-game/ |title=Battle of the Bees: Two games put a new spin on traditional dreidel game |publisher=Jweekly.com |date=2009-12-03 |accessdate=2011-12-23 |deadurl=no {{Infobox company | name = Duoyi Network | logo = | type = | industry = Video games | fate = | predecessor = <!-- or: | predecessors = --> | successor = <!-- or: | successors = --> | founded = {{Start date and age|2006}} | founder = Xu Youzhen | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | hq_location_city = Guangzhou | hq_location_country = China | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = | products = Shenwu series, Dream World series | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | num_employees = | num_employees_year = <!-- Year of num_employees data (if known) --> | parent = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> }} '''Duoyi Network''' ({{zh|s=多益网络|t=多益網絡|p=Duō Yì Wǎng Luò}}) is a Chinese video game company headquartered in Guangzhou, Guangdong. Founded in 2006 by Xu Youzhen, the company is known for developing some of China’s most acclaimed game franchises including the Shenwu series and the Dream World series.<ref name="yesky.com">{{cite web|url=http://gameonline.yesky.com/207/62658207.shtml|title=3月iOS收入:《神武》手游全球第九中国第一_天极网|website=gameonline.yesky.com}}</ref>. Their most recent projects include the third generation of the Shenwu series Shenwu 3<ref name="duoyi.com">{{cite web|url=https://sw3.duoyi.com/news/news_9629.shtm|title=青春相伴 快乐神武3:新闻中心-《神武3》官网-多益网络|website=sw3.duoyi.com}}</ref>, the cross-platform game for the Dream World franchise Dream World 3D<ref name="duoyi.com1">{{cite web|url=https://mx3d.duoyi.com/act/yuyue/|title=梦想世界3D公测预约-6月30日正式起航-《梦想世界3D》官网|website=mx3d.duoyi.com}}</ref>, the 3D MMORPG Eternal Magic<ref>{{cite web|url=https://yh.duoyi.com/news/news_9342.shtm|title=《永恒魔法》2.0全新内容明日公测！魔幻网游革命致敬经典:永恒魔法新闻中心-资讯-活动-攻略-永恒魔法官网|website=yh.duoyi.com}}</ref>, the mobile turn-based RPG Legion of Knights<ref>{{cite web|url=https://szwy.duoyi.com/news/news_9584.shtm|title=《神之物语》全新内容安卓删档测试今日开启:《神之物语》新闻中心-下载-礼包-《神之物语》手游官网|website=szwy.duoyi.com}}</ref>, the multiplayer sandplay SLG Circle of War<ref>{{cite web|url=https://zz.duoyi.com/|title=《战争之轮》手游官网-沙盘战争策略手游-下载-礼包-多益网络|website=zz.duoyi.com}}</ref>, and the sandbox RPG Portal Knights<ref name="qq.com">{{cite web|url=http://games.qq.com/a/20170412/027001.htm|title=《传送门骑士》进军国内 多益网络获国服独家代理权_游戏_腾讯网|website=games.qq.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://csm.duoyi.com/news/news_9699.shtm|title=《传送门骑士》11月21日上线 系列狂欢活动赠豪礼:《传送门骑士Portal Knights》来中国啦！官网预约正式开启，我们的世界需要冒险家！|website=csm.duoyi.com}}</ref>.
In 2015, Duoyi reached a net profit of USD 150 million with a 50% growth rate and ranked the 4th among Chinese game companies in iOS revenue<ref>{{cite web|url=http://games.qq.com/a/20160602/048864.htm|title=多益网络去年净利润超10亿 发布2款端游2款手游新品_游戏_腾讯网|website=games.qq.com}}</ref>. In 2016, the company kept the same level of performance and started IPO<ref>http://www.csrc.gov.cn/pub/zjhpublic/G00306202/201606/P020160624341807655981.pdf</ref>. Duoyi ranked 25th among the [[Ministry of Industry and Information Technology|MIIT]]’s 2017 Top 100 Chinese Internet Enterprises, and 4th among all game companies in China.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://tech.cnr.cn/techgd/20170803/t20170803_523883785.shtml|title=2017中国互联网企业百强公布 腾讯阿里百度连续五年居前三_央广网|first=|last=小花|website=tech.cnr.cn}}</ref>
==History==
Duoyi Network was founded by Xu Youzhen, one of China's most well-known game designers since the early 2000s. Before founding Duoyi Network, Xu was the main designer of Fantasy Westward Journey and responsible for the architecture of the core gameplay. He led the development of Dream World and Shenwu as the founder and president of Duoyi Network.
On September 24, 2007, Duoyi released its first PC title Dream World, a 2D turn-based MMORPG. In 2008, Duoyi received the Gold Finger Award from the China Cultural Industry Association for the creation of Dream World<ref>{{cite web|url=http://game.people.com.cn/GB/48647/139736/141365/8540473.html|title=2008年度中国游戏行业金手指奖--人民网游戏_最权威中文游戏网站--人民网|first=|last=1477|website=game.people.com.cn}}</ref>.
In 2010, Duoyi released Dream Emperor, a strategy mini-client game<ref>{{cite web|url=http://games.qq.com/a/20100611/000183.htm|title=客户端网页游戏《梦想帝王》震撼公测_游戏_腾讯网|website=games.qq.com}}</ref>, and Shenwu, a turn-based MMORPG based on the story line of [[Journey to the West]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sw3.duoyi.com/news/1/lZUxrf.html|title=《神武》快乐公测，超级盛典礼不断：《神武》官网-2010年最新免费网络游戏 回合制网游 绿色免费|website=sw3.duoyi.com}}</ref>.
In 2011, Duoyi launched Tank Force!, an action mobile game that hit no.1 on the App Store Download Chart. In 2012, Duoyi ranked the 40th of “China’s Top 100 Internet Companies” jointly released by Internet Society of China and MIIT<ref>{{cite web|url=http://r.dsnlinks.com/1126/|title=2012 - 中国互联网百强 - 榜上有名|date=13 October 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
In 2015, Duoyi released Shenwu Mobile, which hit the first on App Store Grossing Chart in China and 9th globally<ref name="yesky.com"/>. Shenwu Mobile remained a top 10 grossing app for over 80 consecutive weeks. Shenwu 2, a major expansion set for both Shenwu PC and Shenwu Mobile, was released on July 3, 2015<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sw3.duoyi.com/news/1/oMxyFY.html|title=《神武2》今日公测开启 全新内容快乐启航：《神武2》官网-快乐免费回合制网游-2017好玩的网络游戏 绿色免费-多益网络|website=sw3.duoyi.com}}</ref>. On March 19, 2016, Shenwu 2 received two Gold Finger Awards for Excellent Online Game and Excellent Mobile Game at the Chinese Game Industry Annual Conference<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nadianshi.com/2016/03/108318|title=观察 - 多益网络斩获“金手指”四项大奖 载誉而归 - 手游那点事|website=www.nadianshi.com}}</ref>. Shenwu 3, the second major expansion set for the Shenwu franchise, was released on December 24, 2017<ref name="duoyi.com"/>.
Dream World Mobile and Dream World 3D were released respectively in June 2015 and July 2017<ref>{{cite web|url=https://mxsy.duoyi.com/news/news_3368.shtm|title=《梦想世界》手游全平台测试开启:新闻中心-梦想世界手游官方网站 - 梦想世界手游安卓版 - 梦想世界手游下载 - 梦想世界手游礼包 -多益网络|website=mxsy.duoyi.com}}</ref><ref name="duoyi.com1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://finance.jrj.com.cn/tech/2017/06/30163923781131.shtml|title=回合真策略梦想新经典 《梦想世界3D》今日全平台公测|date=30 June 2017|website=金融界}}</ref>. In December 2017, the Dream World franchise announced its 10th Anniversary Event<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mx.duoyi.com/act/2017/ten/?f=xwtt|title=《梦想世界》十周年庆典 经典活动再临-《梦想世界》官网|website=mx.duoyi.com}}</ref>.
Duoyi established partnership with [[505 Games]] for the exclusive right to operate [[Portal Knights]], a survival action role-playing game, in China<ref name="qq.com"/>. Duoyi released Portal Knights in China on November 21, 2017.
In 2017, Duoyi Network ranked the 25th of “China’s Top 100 Internet Companies”, released by Internet Society of China and MIIT, and the 4th among game companies in China.<ref name="auto"/>

A '''background actor''' or '''extra''' is a [[performer]] in a [[film]], [[television show]], stage, musical, opera or ballet production, who appears in a nonspeaking or nonsinging (silent) capacity, usually in the background (for example, in an audience or busy street scene). [[War film]]s and [[epic film]]s often employ background actors in large numbers: some films have featured hundreds or even thousands of paid background actors as cast members (hence the term "cast of thousands"). Likewise, [[grand opera]] can involve many background actors appearing in spectacular productions.
On a film or TV set, background actors are usually referred to as "atmosphere", "background talent", "background performers", "background artists", "background cast members" or simply "background", while the term "extra" is rarely used.<ref>[http://tophollywoodactingcoach.com/2012/01/background_actors_extra_atmosphere/ Background Actors, Extras or Atmosphere?] ''tophollywoodactingcoach'' Published by Ross, Mae; 3-2-1 Acting. Accessed 22 May 2018</ref> In a stage production, background actors are commonly referred to as "[[supernumeraries]]". In opera and ballet, they are called either "extras" or "supers".
==Casting== Casting criteria for background actors depend on the production. It is not entirely true that background cast members require little or no [[acting]] experience, as any type of unrealistic portrayal must include some form of imagination and acting. Punctuality, reliability and the ability to take direction also figure prominently for these cast members. Background actors are often selected on short notice, after all other preparations for the shoot have been finalized.<ref name="Kelly">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ftbWjFvRMZ4C&printsec=frontcover&dq=extra+actor&hl=en&sa=X&ei=5Rs_Upa2IoTtigK2mYHYBQ&ved=0CEYQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=extra%20actor&f=false|title=The Truth About Being an Extra: How to Become a Good Background Actor|author=Jo Kelly|publisher=Google Books|accessdate=1 July 2014}}</ref>
Several casting agencies specialize only in background work, whilst in the UK the directory ''Contacts'' published annually by [[Spotlight (Casting Services Company)|Spotlight]] lists all accredited agencies and productions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/faqs/about/extra|title=How to be an Extra|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=1 July 2014}}</ref><ref name="MMagpie" /> Some agencies charge a registration fee, and some (mostly commercial background casting) will take between 10% and 15% commission from any booked work. Artists may be required to provide a basic one-page A4 sized CV/resume, that states basic personal details and dimensions, any significant skills (e.g. [[stage combat]]), and includes two 8x10 inch photographs on the rear: one head shot; one full body shot.<ref name="Kelly" /><ref name="MMagpie" /><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-10557/How-movie-extra.html|title=How to be a movie extra|publisher=[[Daily Mail]]|accessdate=1 July 2014}}</ref>
When hiring background actors, casting directors generally seek those with a specific "look", such as "high school students" or "affluent senior citizens", consistent with the context of the film. Casting directors may also look for background actors with a special skill for the scene, such as [[rollerblading]], or dancing. A background actor is often expected to bring his or her own wardrobe to the set, although there are also "fittings" for a specific scene or period. A casting director may favor the one who already has the required costume or prop, such as a police uniform, or a musical instrument. On other occasions, where a costume has already been prepared (for example, to fit another actor who is now unavailable), a background actor may be selected as a "costume double" simply because they are the right size to fit it. On smaller productions or student films, background actors may be hired ''en masse'' with little formality.<ref name="Kelly" />
The length of a background actor's employment on a production largely depends on the needs of the director and the scenes being filmed. Some background actors are needed on the set only for a day or two, while others may remain with the film for an extended period. For instance, on [[James Cameron]]'s film ''[[Titanic (1997 film)|Titanic]]'', a group of 150 "core background actors" was hired to play the ship's passengers, and employed throughout the filming.
==Salary and working conditions== {{Globalize|section|date=August 2010}}
===United Kingdom=== In the [[United Kingdom]], the distinction between an actor and an extra is defined by agreements between the actors [[trade union]]s [[Broadcasting, Entertainment, Cinematograph and Theatre Union|Broadcasting Entertainment Cinematograph and Theatre Union (BECTU)]] and [[Equity (trade union)|Equity]], and the various commercial trade and production bodies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bectu.org.uk/get-involved/background-artistes |title=Background Artistes |publisher=BECTU |date=2011-07-01 |accessdate=2013-03-26}}</ref> These state that once a performer says 13 or more words in any scene, they must become a contracted actor in that production.<ref name="EquityRA" /> Minimum pay rates are defined by UK Government minimum wage regulations, and both BECTU and Equity have agreed rates with each body. However, even on non-union productions an extra's pay is an agreed day-rate for ten hours of production time.<ref name=MMagpie>{{cite web|url=http://www.moneymagpie.com/article/make-money-being-a-film-or-tv-extra|title=Make money being a film or TV extra|publisher=Money Magpie|accessdate=1 July 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140730221918/http://www.moneymagpie.com/article/make-money-being-a-film-or-tv-extra|archivedate=30 July 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> All performers under agreement with BECTU/Equity are paid on-going royalties. Hence on many advertisements, which are often shown multiple times and distributed internationally, whilst the extra is paid a contracted day-rate, the largest payment is nominally due from ongoing royalties. Due to the resultant complex calculations from multiple international showings, performers under a union managed agreement are often bought-out of their advertisement royalties with a one-off payment.<ref name="EquityRA">{{cite web|url=http://www.equity.org.uk/resource-centre/rates-and-agreements/|title=Rates and Agreements - Members Guide & Pamphlet|publisher=[[Equity (trade union)|Equity]]|accessdate=1 July 2014}}</ref>
===United States=== In the United States, most major film and television productions used to fall under the jurisdiction of the [[Screen Actors Guild]] (SAG) or [[American Federation of Television and Radio Artists|AFTRA]]. The two unions have merged into [[SAG-AFTRA]].
SAG-signatory [[Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers|producers]] are allowed to hire non-union background actors after a certain number of SAG performers have been cast; non-union background actors are usually paid the minimum wage. On productions outside of union jurisdiction, payment for background actors is at the discretion of the producers, and ranges from [[Trade Union|union]]-scale rates to "copy and credit" (i.e., no pay). Those producers who do not pay their actors may be in violation of state and federal laws about minimum wage for a job.
Between 1946 and 1992, background actors in film and television were largely represented by the '''Screen Extras Guild.''' SEG was disbanded on 1 June 1992 and transferred its jurisdiction to SAG.<ref>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1153/is_n8_v115/ai_12624085 Television and movie agreement - collective bargaining agreement; Screen Actors Guild, American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers], Monthly Labor Review, August 1992</ref>
==In popular culture==
The silent film ''[[The Extra Girl]]'' (1923) portrays a small-town girl who comes to [[Hollywood]] and becomes a background actor in her attempt to achieve stardom.
The British television sitcom ''[[Extras (TV series)|Extras]]'' (2005–07) follows the exploits of two professional background actors, Andy and Maggie. They spend most of their time on set looking for a speaking role and a boyfriend, respectively.
In the Hindi [[black comedy]] film ''[[Mithya]]'' (2008), the protagonist is a background actor whose facial similarity to an underworld [[Boss (crime)|crime boss]] lands him in trouble.
The Filipino [[comedy-drama]] film ''[[Ekstra]]'' (''The Bit Player'') (2013) centers around the life of a divorcee named Loida Malabanan, whose [[temporary work|odd job]] as a bit player for various acting roles enabled her to send her daughter to college.<ref name=ekstravariety>{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/global/the-bit-player-review-toronto-1200607975/|title=Toronto Film Review: ‘The Bit Player’|last=Kuipers|first=Richard|publisher=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=September 11, 2013|accessdate=December 3, 2018}}</ref> The movie is a [[social commentary]] on the exploitation and mistreatment of the [[marginalized]] sector in the [[television production]] industry in the Philippines.<ref name="ekstra blog">{{cite blog|url=https://said-fred.blogspot.com/2013/07/ekstra-excellent-paradox.html|title=EKSTRA: An Excellent Paradox|last=Hawson|first=Fred|publisher=[[Blogger (service)|Blogger]]|date=July 29, 2013|accessdate=December 3, 2018}}</ref><ref name=ekstraINQ>{{cite news|url=https://opinion.inquirer.net/59179/ekstra-the-country-in-miniature|title='Ekstra': The country in miniature|last=Jimenez-David|first=Rina|publisher=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=August 19, 2013|accessdate=December 3, 2018}}</ref><ref name=ekstrarev>{{cite blog|url=https://ilusyonaryo.wordpress.com/2014/12/11/a-review-paper-for-ekstra-2013-a-film-by-jeffrey-jeturian/|title=A review paper for Ekstra (2013): A film by Jeffrey Jeturian|<!--author=migibytes-->|website=ilusyonaryo.com|publisher=[[WordPress]]|date=December 11, 2014|accessdate=December 3, 2018}}</ref>
The Chinese-Hong Kong film ''[[I Am Somebody]]'' (2015) is about extras working at the [[Hengdian World Studios]].<ref>{{cite web |url= https://variety.com/2015/film/asia/i-am-somebody-review-derek-yee-shanghai-film-festival-1201519295/|title= Film Review: 'I Am Somebody' |first=Maggie |last=Lee |date=17 June 2015 |accessdate=10 October 2015 |work=[[variety.com]] }}</ref>

[[File:Filmdaase.jpg|thumb|Stacked film cans containing rolls of film.]] [[File:EYE Film Institute Netherlands - Nitrate film decay - 1.jpg|thumb|Decayed nitrate film. EYE Film Institute Netherlands.]] [[File:EYE Film Institute Netherlands - Nitrate film decay - 3.JPG|thumb|Decayed nitrate film. EYE Film Institute Netherlands.]] '''Film preservation''', or '''film restoration''', describes a series of ongoing efforts among film historians, archivists, museums, [[cinematheque]]s, and [[non-profit organization]]s to rescue decaying [[film stock]] and preserve the images which they contain. In the widest sense, preservation nowadays assures that a movie will continue to exist in as close to its original form as possible.<ref name="McGreevey, Tom 1997">{{cite book|last=Yeck|first=Joanne L.|title=Our Movie Heritage|year=1997|publisher=Rutgers University Press|location=New Brunswick, NJ [u.a.]|isbn=0813524318|author2=Tom McGreevey}}</ref>
For many years the term "preservation" was synonymous with "duplication" of film. The goal of a preservationist was to create a durable copy without any significant loss of [[image quality|quality]]. In more modern terms, film preservation now includes the concepts of handling, duplication, storage, and access. The archivist seeks to protect the film and share the content with the public.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Film Preservation Guide: The Basics for Archives, Libraries, and Museums|year=2004|publisher=National Film Preservation Foundation|location=[[San Francisco]]|isbn=0974709905|url=http://www.filmpreservation.org/preservation-basics/the-film-preservation-guide}}</ref>
Film preservation is not to be confused with film [[Revisionism (fictional)|revisionism]], in which long-completed films are subjected to [[outtake]]s never previously seen being inserted, newly inserted music scores or sound effects being added, black-and-white film being [[Film colorization|colorized]] or converted to [[Dolby]] stereo, or minor [[film editing|edits]] and other cosmetic changes being made.
By the 1980s, it was becoming apparent that the collections of motion picture heritage were at risk of becoming lost. Not only was the preservation of [[Nitrocellulose#Nitrate film|nitrate film]] an ongoing problem, but the discovery that safety film, used as a replacement for the more volatile nitrate stock, was beginning to be affected by a unique form of decay known as "[[Cellulose acetate film#Decay and the "vinegar syndrome"|vinegar syndrome]]", and color film manufactured, in particular, by [[Eastman Kodak]], was found to be at risk of fading. At that time, the best known solution was to duplicate the original film onto a more secure medium.
90 percent of all American [[silent films]] made before 1929 and 50 percent of American [[sound film]]s made before 1950 are [[lost films]].<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Dave Kehr|Kehr, Dave]]|title=Film Riches, Cleaned Up for Posterity |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/15/movies/15restore.html|quote=It’s bad enough, to cite a common estimate, that 90 percent of all American silent films and 50 percent of American sound films made before 1950 appear to have vanished forever.|work=[[New York Times]]|date=14 October 2010|accessdate=23 July 2015}}</ref>
Although institutional practices of film preservation date back to the 1930s,<ref>Houston, P. (1994). Keepers of the frame: the film archives. British Film Institute.</ref> the field received an official status only in 1980, when UNESCO recognized "moving images" as an integral part of the world's cultural heritage.<ref>[http://portal.unesco.org/en/ev.php-URL_ID=13139&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html UNESCO, Recommendation for the Safeguarding and Preservation of Moving Images] at UNESCO.org, 27 October 1980. Accessed 23 July 2015</ref>
==Film decay== {{see also|Lost film}} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Nitratedecomp.png|thumb|320px|An extreme example of nitrate decomposition.]] --> The great majority of films made in the [[silent film|silent]] era are now considered [[lost films|lost]] forever. Movies of the first half of the 20th century were filmed on an unstable, highly flammable [[Nitrocellulose|cellulose nitrate]] [[film base]], which required careful storage to slow its inevitable process of decomposition over time. Most films made on nitrate stock were not preserved; over the years, their negatives and prints crumbled into powder or dust. Many of them were recycled for their silver content, or destroyed in studio or vault fires. The largest cause, however, was intentional destruction. As film preservationist Robert A. Harris explains, "Most of the early films did not survive because of wholesale junking by the studios. There was no thought of ever saving these films. They simply needed vault space and the materials were expensive to house."<ref>{{cite web|last=Hart|first=Martin|title=Robert A. Harris Presentation on Film Preservation|url=http://www.widescreenmuseum.com/rah.htm|publisher=American WideScreen Museum|date=February 1993}}</ref> [[Silent film]]s had little or no commercial value after the advent of sound films in the 1930s, and as such, they were not kept. As a result, preserving the now rare silent films has been a high priority amongst [[History of film|film historians]].
Because of the fragility of [[film stock]], proper preservation of film usually involves storing the original negatives (if they have survived) and prints in climate-controlled facilities. The vast majority of films were not stored in this manner, which resulted in the widespread decay of film stocks.
The problem of film decay is not limited to films made on [[Nitrocellulose|cellulose nitrate]]. Film industry researchers and specialists have found that color films (those made in the processes which replaced [[Technicolor]]) are also decaying at an increasingly rapid rate. A number of well-known films only exist as copies of original [[film production]]s or exhibition elements because the originals have decomposed beyond use. [[Cellulose acetate film]], which was the initial replacement for nitrate, has been found to suffer from "[[Cellulose acetate film#Decay and the "vinegar syndrome"|vinegar syndrome]]". The ongoing preservation of color films is now presented with an issue, as low temperatures, which inhibit color fading, actually increase the effects of vinegar syndrome, while higher (normal room) temperatures cause color fading.{{dubious | August 2018 |reason=Vinegar syndrome article says the opposite.|date=August 2018}}{{citation needed|date=August 2018}}
===Film decay as an art form=== In 2002, filmmaker [[Bill Morrison (director)|Bill Morrison]] produced ''[[Decasia]]'', a film solely based on fragments of old unrestored nitrate-based films in various states of decay and disrepair, providing a somewhat eerie aesthetic to the film. The film was paired together with a soundtrack composed by [[Michael Gordon (composer)|Michael Gordon]], and performed by his orchestra. The footage used was from old newsreel & archive film, and was obtained by Morrison from several sources, such as the [http://www.sc.edu/library/newsfilm/ Fox Movietone Newsfilm Archives] at the [[University of South Carolina]], and the archives of the [[Museum of Modern Art]].
==Preservation through careful storage== [[File:PackardHumanities Institute, Santa Clarita.jpg|thumb|right|[[Packard Humanities Institute]], Santa Clarita, [[Nitrate film]] Film Vault]] The "preservation" of film usually refers to physical storage of the film in a [[HVAC|climate-controlled]] vault, and sometimes to the actual repair and copying of the film element. Preservation is different from "restoration", as restoration is the act of returning the film to a version most faithful to its initial release to the public and often involves combining various fragments of film elements.
Film is best preserved by proper protection from external forces while in storage along with being under controlled temperatures.<ref name="McGreevey, Tom 1997"/> For most film materials, the [[Image Permanence Institute]] finds that storing film media in frozen temperatures, with RH between 30% and 50%, greatly extends its useful life.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Film Preservation Guide: The Basics for Archives, Libraries, and Museums|last=|first=|publisher=The National Film Preservation Foundation|year=2004|isbn=0974709905|location=|pages=61|quote=|via=}}</ref> These measures inhibit deterioration better than any other methods and is a cheaper solution than replicating deteriorating films.
==Preparing a film for preservation and restoration==
In most cases, when a film is chosen for preservation or restoration work, new prints are created from the [[original camera negative]] or the ''composite restoration negative'' which is often made from a combination of elements for general screening.
The composite restoration negative is a compilation of duplicated sections of the best remaining material, recombined to approximate the original configuration of the original camera negative at some time in the film's release cycle, while the [[original camera negative]] is the remaining, edited, film negative that passed through the camera on the set. This original camera negative may, or may not, remain in original release form, depending upon number of subsequent re-releases after the initial release for theatrical exhibition.
In traditional photochemical restorations, image polarity considerations must be observed when recombining surviving materials and the final, lowest generation restoration master may be either a duplicate negative or a [[fine grain master positive]].
Preservation elements, such as fine-grain master positives and duplicate printing negatives, are generated from this restoration master element to make both duplication masters and access projection prints available for future generations.
==Film as archival medium==
Film preservationists would prefer that the film images, whether restored through photochemical or digital processes, be eventually transferred to other film stock, because no digital media exists that has proven truly archival because of rapidly evolving and shifting data formats, while a well-developed and stored, modern film print can last upwards of 100 years.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://twitchfilm.com/2012/09/jason-gorbers-cineruminations-70mm-4k-and-the-master-split-personality.html |title=twitchfilm.com. Jason Gorber's Cineruminations: 70mm, 4K, and THE MASTER's Split Personality Jason Gorber |access-date=2014-04-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140217215841/http://twitchfilm.com/2012/09/jason-gorbers-cineruminations-70mm-4k-and-the-master-split-personality.html |archive-date=2014-02-17 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
While some in the archival community feel that conversion from film to a digital image results in a loss of quality that can make it more difficult to create a high-quality print based upon the digital image, digital imaging technology has become increasingly advanced to the point where 8K scanners can capture the full resolution of images filmed at as high as 65mm.<ref name="postmagazine.com">[http://www.postmagazine.com/Publications/Post-Magazine/2012/November-1-2012/Sound-Picture-Restoration.aspx postmagazine.com, Issue: November 1, 2012, Sound & Picture Restoration, By: Christine Bunish]</ref> 70mm IMAX has a resolution of 18K, which is the upper necessary limit for film capture in full resolution.<ref>[[Image resolution]]</ref>
Of course, having an intermediate digital stage, followed by forming a new film master by lasering the digital results onto new film stock does represent an extra generation. So would an intermediate film master that was restored frame-by-frame by hand. The choice of film vs. digital restoration will be driven by the amount, if any, of restoration required, the taste and skill set of the restorer, and the economics of film restoration vs. digital restoration.
==Digital as archival medium==
Digital scanners {{as of|2014|lc=y}} can capture images as large as 65mm in full resolution.<ref name="postmagazine.com"/> That is the typical image size on a traditional (as opposed to the IMAX process) 70mm film which used a portion of the film surface for its multitrack magnetic sound stripe. A 70mm print of a two and a half hour film {{as of|2012|lc=y}} ran upwards of $170,000. A hard disk capable of storing such a movie is a few hundred dollars. An archival optical disk will be less. The problem of having to transfer the data as new generations of equipment come along will continue, however, until true archival standards are put in place.
==Digital film preservation==
In the context of film preservation the term "[[digital preservation]]" highlights the use of digital technology for the transfer of films from 8mm to 70mm in size to digital [[digital media|carriers]], as well as all practices for ensuring the longevity and access to [[Digitizing|digitized]] or [[Born-digital|digitally born]] film materials. On purely technical and practical terms, digital film preservation stands for a domain specific subset of [[digital curation]] practices. Extensive technical literature on the subject can be found at the online library of the Presto Centre Project.<ref>[https://www.prestocentre.org/ Presto Centre Project web site]</ref>
The [[aesthetic]] and [[ethical]] implications of the use of digital technology for film preservation are major subjects of debate. For instance, the senior curator of [[George Eastman House]] Paolo Cherchi Usai has decried the shift from analogue to digital preservation of film as ethically unacceptable, arguing, on philosophical terms, that the medium of film is an essential ontological precondition for the existence of cinema.<ref>Usai, Paolo Cherchi (2001) "The death of cinema: history, cultural memory and the digital dark age" British Film Institute</ref> More recently, the senior curator of [[EYE Film Institute Netherlands]] Giovanna Fossati has discussed the use of digital technologies for the restoration and preservation of film in a more optimistic way as a form of [[Remediation (Marxist theory)|remediation]] of the cinematic medium, and has positively reflected on digital technologies' ability to broaden restoration possibilities, improve quality, and reduce costs.<ref>Fossati, Giovanna (2009) "From grain to pixel: the archival life of film in transition." Amsterdam University Press</ref> According to the cinema scholar Leo Enticknap, the views held by Usai and Fossati could be seen as representative of the two poles of the digital debate in film preservation.<ref>Enticknap, Leo (2012). "Dossier: Materiality and the Archive." The Velvet Light Trap, (70), 63-64</ref> It should be kept in mind, however, that both Usai and Fossati's arguments are highly complex and nuanced, and likewise, the debate about the utility of digital technologies in film preservation is complex and continually evolving.
==Advancements== In 1935, New York's [[Museum of Modern Art]] began one of the earliest institutional attempts to collect and preserve motion pictures, obtaining original negatives of the [[American Mutoscope and Biograph Company|Biograph]] and Edison companies, and the world's largest collection of [[D. W. Griffith]] films.<ref>{{cite web|title=MoMA.org {{!}} The Collection {{!}} Film and Media |url=http://www.moma.org/collection/depts/film_media/ |work=[[The Museum of Modern Art]] |accessdate=23 June 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060207232551/http://www.moma.org/collection/depts/film_media/ |archivedate=February 7, 2006 |deadurl=unfit }}</ref> The following year, [[Henri Langlois]] founded the [[Cinémathèque Française]] in Paris, which would become the world's largest international film collection.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cinematheque.fr/data/document/expositionpermanente.pdf |title=Passion Cinéma |access-date=2006-05-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060627162200/http://www.cinematheque.fr/data/document/expositionpermanente.pdf |archive-date=2006-06-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
For thousands of early silent films stored in the [[Library of Congress]], mostly between 1894 and 1912, the only existing copies were printed on [[paper print|rolls of paper]] submitted as copyright registrations.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.loc.gov/rr/mopic/earlymps.html#pape |title=Early Motion Pictures Free of Copyright Restrictions in the Library of Congress |publisher=Library of Congress |date=31 August 2010|accessdate=14 April 2011}}</ref> For these, an [[optical printer]] was used to copy these images onto safety film stock, a project that began in 1947 and continues today.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} The Library hosts the National Film Preservation Board, whose National Film Registry annually selects 25 U.S. films "showcasing the range and diversity of American film heritage."<ref>[https://www.loc.gov/programs/national-film-preservation-board/about-this-program Library of Congress-LOC Film preservation]</ref> The [[George Eastman House International Museum of Photography and Film]] was chartered in 1947 to collect, preserve and present the history of photography and film, and in 1996 opened the Louis B. Mayer Conservation Center, one of only four film conservation centers in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eastmanhouse.org/inc/the_museum/history.php |title=Museum History · George Eastman House |publisher=Eastmanhouse.org |accessdate=14 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006120017/http://eastmanhouse.org/inc/the_museum/history.php |archivedate=October 6, 2008 }}</ref> The [[American Film Institute]] was founded in 1967 to train the next generation of filmmakers and preserve the American film heritage.<ref>{{cite web|author=American Film Institute|url=http://www.afi.com/about/history.aspx|title=History of AFI|publisher=Afi.com|accessdate=14 April 2011}}</ref> Its collection now includes over 27,500 titles.
In 1978, [[Dawson City]], [[Yukon Territory]], Canada, a construction excavation inadvertently found a forgotten collection of more than 500 discarded films from the early 20th century that were buried in and preserved in the [[permafrost]].<ref>Kula, S. (1979). Rescued from the Permafrost: The Dawson Collection of Motion Pictures. ''Archivaria,'' No. 8, Summer 1979.</ref> This fortunate discovery was shared and moved to the United States' [[Library of Congress]]<ref>Shepard, R. (1990, Sept. 3). Expanding Archives: Library of Congress Is Not Just Books. ''The New York Times.''</ref> and [[Library and Archives Canada]] for transfer to safety stock and archiving.<ref>[http://www.bac-lac.gc.ca/eng/about-us/preservation/Pages/preservation.aspx The Library and Archives Canada Preservation Centre]</ref> However, to move such highly flammable material such a distance ultimately required assistance from the [[Canadian Armed Forces]] to make the delivery to [[Ottawa]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Morrison|first1=Bill|title=Dawson City: Frozen Time|date=2016|publisher=KinoLorber|page=1:53:45|accessdate=7 January 2018}}</ref> The story of this discovery as well as excerpts of these films can be seen in the 2016 [[documentary film]], ''[[Dawson City: Frozen Time]]''.
Another high-profile restoration by staff at the [[British Film Institute]]'s [[National Film and Television Archive]] is the [[Mitchell and Kenyon]] collection, which consists almost entirely of [[actuality film]]s commissioned by traveling fairground operators for showing at local fairgrounds or other venues across the UK in the early part of the twentieth century. The collection was stored for many decades in two large barrels following the winding-up of the firm, and was discovered in [[Blackburn]] in the early 1990s. The restored films now offer a unique social record of early 20th-century British life.<ref>[http://www.bfi.org.uk/archive-collections/about-bfi-national-archive About the BFI National Archive] at British Film Institute official web site</ref>
Individual preservationists who have contributed to the cause include [[Robert A. Harris]] and [[James Katz]] (''[[Lawrence of Arabia (film)|Lawrence of Arabia]]'', ''[[My Fair Lady (film)|My Fair Lady]]'', and several [[Alfred Hitchcock]] films), Michael Thau (''[[Superman (1978 film)|Superman]]''), and [[Kevin Brownlow]] (''[[Intolerance (film)|Intolerance]]'' and ''[[Napoléon (1927 film)|Napoleon]]''). Other organizations, such as the [[UCLA Film and Television Archive]], have also preserved and restored films; a major part of UCLA's work includes such projects as ''[[Becky Sharp (film)|Becky Sharp]]'' and select [[Paramount Pictures|Paramount]]/[[Famous Studios]] and [[Warner Bros.]] cartoons whose credits were once altered due to rights taken over by different entities.
==Studio efforts== In 1926 [[Will H. Hays|Will Hays]] asked for [[film studio]]s to preserve their films by storing them at 40 degrees at low humidity in an [[Eastman Kodak]] process, so that "schoolboys in the year 3,000 and 4,000 A.D. may learn about us".<ref>{{cite news|last=Johnston|first=Alva| authorlink = Alva Johnston|title=Films Put on Ice for Fans yet Unborn|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=24 October 1926|quote=Will Hays has sent a call to the motion-picture companies to search their vaults for ancient films of all kinds and for news reels of possible historic interest. The most important of these are to be treated by a process developed in the Eastman laboratories for making films immortal.}}</ref>
Beginning in the 1970s, [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]], aware that the original negatives to many of its Golden Age films had been destroyed in a fire, began a preservation program to restore and preserve all of its films by using whatever negatives survived, or, in many cases, the next best available elements (whether it be a fine-grain master positive or mint archival print). From the onset, it was determined that if some films had to be preserved, then it would have to be ''all'' of them. In 1986, when [[Ted Turner]] acquired MGM's library (which by then had included [[Warner Bros.]]' pre-1950,<ref>{{cite book|last=Schickel|first=Richard| authorlink = Richard Schickel|title=You Must Remember This: The Warner Bros. Story|year=2008|publisher=Running Press|location=Philadelphia|isbn=076243418X|author2=Perry, George}}</ref><ref group="nb">Warner Bros. retained a pair of features from 1949 that they merely distributed, and all short subjects released on or after September 1, 1948, in addition to all cartoons released in August 1948.</ref> MGM's pre-May 1986, and a majority of the [[RKO Radio Pictures]] catalogs), he vowed to continue the preservation work MGM had started. [[Time Warner]], the current owner of [[Turner Entertainment]], continues this work today.
The cause for film preservation came to the forefront in the 1980s and early 1990s when such famous and influential film directors as [[Steven Spielberg]] and [[Martin Scorsese]] contributed to the cause. Spielberg became interested in film preservation when he went to view the master of his film ''[[Jaws (film)|Jaws]],'' only to find that it had badly decomposed and deteriorated—a mere fifteen years after it had been filmed. Scorsese drew attention to the film industry's use of color-fading film stock through his use of black-and-white film stock in his 1980 film ''[[Raging Bull]]''.{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}} His film, ''[[Hugo (film)|Hugo]]'' included a key scene in which many of film pioneer [[Georges Méliès]]' silent films are melted down and the raw material recycled as shoes; this was seen by many movie critics as "a passionate brief for film preservation wrapped in a fanciful tale of childhood intrigue and adventure."<ref>{{cite web|last=McCarthy|first=Todd| authorlink =Todd McCarthy|title=Hugo: Film Review |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movie/hugo/review/263209|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=23 June 2013|date=17 November 2013}}</ref>
Scorsese's concern about the need to save motion pictures of the past led him to create [[The Film Foundation]], a non-profit organization dedicated to film preservation, in 1990. He was joined in this effort by fellow film makers who served on the foundation's board of directors—[[Woody Allen]], [[Robert Altman]], [[Francis Ford Coppola]], [[Clint Eastwood]], [[Stanley Kubrick]], [[George Lucas]], [[Sydney Pollack]], [[Robert Redford]], and [[Steven Spielberg]]. In 2006, [[Paul Thomas Anderson]], [[Wes Anderson]], [[Curtis Hanson]], [[Peter Jackson]], [[Ang Lee]], and [[Alexander Payne]] were added to the board of directors of The Film Foundation, which is aligned with the [[Directors Guild of America]].{{citation needed|date=June 2013}}
By working in partnership with the leading film archives and studios, The Film Foundation has saved nearly 600 films, often restoring them to pristine condition. In many cases, original footage that had been excised—or [[censorship|censored]] by the [[Production Code]] in the U.S.—from the original negative, has been reinstated. In addition to the preservation, restoration, and presentation of classic cinema, the foundation teaches young people about film language and history through ''The Story of Movies'', an educational program claimed to be "used by over 100,000 educators nationwide".<ref>[http://www.storyofmovies.org/common/11041/aboutFoundation.cfm?clientID=11041 About the Foundation] at storyofmovies.org</ref>
In the age of [[digital television]], [[high definition television]] and [[DVD]], film preservation and restoration has taken on commercial as well as historical importance, since audiences demand the highest possible picture quality from digital formats. Meanwhile, the dominance of [[home video]] and ever-present need for [[television broadcasting]] content, especially on [[specialty channel]]s, has meant that films have proven a source of long-term revenue to a degree that the original artists and studio management before the rise of these media never imagined. Thus media companies have a strong financial incentive to carefully archive and preserve their complete library of films.
==Video Aids to Film Preservation== The group Video Aids to Film Preservation (VAFP) became active on the Internet in 2005.
The VAFP site was funded as part of a 2005 [[Institute of Museum and Library Services]] (IMLS) grant to the [[Folkstreams]] project. The purpose of the site is to supplement already existing film preservation guides provided by the [[National Film Preservation Foundation]] with video demonstrations.<ref>{{cite web|title=Video Aids to Film Preservation|url=http://www.folkstreams.net/vafp/#content|work=Folkstreams|accessdate=23 June 2013}}</ref> The preservation guides provided by the origination, while thoroughly depicting accurate methods of preservation, are mostly text-based. The films and clips are copyrighted under the [[Creative Commons]] license, which allows anyone to use these clips with attribution—in this case, attribution to the VAFP site and to the author of the clip and his company.
==Obstacles in restoration== Regardless of the age of the print itself, damage may occur if stored improperly. Damage to the film (caused by tears on the print, curling of the film base due to intense light exposure, temperature, humidity, etc.) all significantly raise the difficulty of the preservation process. Many films simply do not have enough information left on the film to piece together a new master, although careful digital restoration can produce stunning results by gathering bits and pieces of buildings from adjacent frames for restoration on a damaged frame, predicting entire frames based on the characters' movements in prior and subsequent frames, etc. As time goes on, this digital capability will only improve, but it will ultimately require sufficient information from the original film to make proper restorations and predictions.
Cost is another obstacle. In 2014, Martin Scorsese's non-profit The Film Foundation, dedicated to film presentation, estimated the average cost of photochemical restoration of a color feature with sound at $50,000 to $100,000 dollars, with digital 2K or 4K restoration at "several hundred thousand dollars."<ref>[http://www.film-foundation.org film-foundation.org FAQ http://www.film-foundation.org/faq]</ref> The degree of physical and chemical damage of film influences the incentive to preserve, i.e. as the business perspective states that once a film is no longer "commercially" viable, it stops generating profit and becomes a financial liability. While few films would not benefit from digital restoration, the high cost of restoring films digitally still prevents the method from being as broadly applied as it might be.
Demand for new media, digital cinema, and constantly-evolving consumer digital formats keeps evolving and shifting. Film restoration facilities must keep pace to maintain audience acceptance. Classic films today must be in near-mint condition if they are to be reshown or resold, with the demand for perfection only rising as theaters move from 2K to 4K projection and consumer media continues its shift from SD to HD to UltraHD and beyond.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}}
==Digital restoration steps==
Once a film is inspected and cleaned it is transferred via [[telecine]] or a [[motion picture film scanner]] to a [[magnetic tape data storage|digital tape]] or [[hard disk drive|disk]], and the audio is synced to create a new [[audio mastering|master]].
The main defects needing restoration: * Dirt/dust * Scratches, tears/[[movie projector#Light source|burned frames]] * Color fade, color change * Excessive [[film grain]] (a copy of an existing film has all of the film grain from the original as well as the film grain in the copy) * Missing scenes and sound (censored or edited out for re-release) * Shrinkage<ref group="nb">Linear and "across the web" (width), as well as localized puckering around large (1 to 2) perforation film cement splices, most common in silent and very early sound films. Highly shrunken film (1.5% or higher), must be copied on modified equipment or the film will most likely be damaged. In the case of inflammable nitrate film, this could prove to be dangerous, as the film can jam in the duplicator and become idle. Some methods of duplication have illumination sources with enough heat to ignite the film if exposed to the light source for a long period of time.</ref> Modern, digital film restoration takes the following steps: <ol type+"1"> <li>Expertly clean the film of dirt and dust. <li>Repair all film tears with clear polyester tape or splicing cement. <li>Scan each frame into a digital file. <li>Restore the film frame by frame by comparing each frame to adjacent frames. This can be done somewhat by computer algorithms with human checking of the result. <ol type="a"> <li>Fix frame alignment ("jitter" and "weave"), or the misalignment of adjacent film frames due to movement of film within the sprockets. This corrects the issue where the holes on each side of a frame are distorted over time. This causes frames to slightly be off center. <li>Fix color and lighting changes. This corrects flickering and slight color changes from one frame to another due to aging of the film. <li>Restore areas blocked by dirt and dust by using parts of images in other frames. <li>Restore scratches by using parts of images in other frames. <li>Enhance frames by reducing film grain noise. Film foreground/background detail about the same size as the film grain or smaller is blurred or lost in making the film. Comparing a frame with adjacent frames allows detail information to be reconstructed since a given small detail may be split between more film grains from one frame to another. </ol> </ol>
== Photochemical restoration steps ==
Modern, photochemical restoration follows roughly the same path as digital: # Extensive research is done to determine what version of the film can be restored from the existing material. Often, extensive efforts are taken to search out alternative material in film archives located around the world. # A comprehensive restoration plan is mapped that allows preservationists to designate elements as "key" elements upon which to base the polarity map for the ensuing photochemical work. Since many alternative elements are actually salvaged from release prints and duplication masters (foreign and domestic). Care must be taken to plot the course at which negative, master positive and release print elements arrive back at a common polarity (i.e., negative or positive) for assembly and subsequent printing. # Test prints are struck from existing elements to evaluate contrast, resolution, color (if color) and sound quality (if audio element exists). # Elements are duplicated using the shortest possible duplication path to minimize analog [[generation loss|duplication artifacts]], such as the build-up of contrast, grain and loss of resolution. # All sources are assembled into a single master restoration element (most often a duplicate negative). # From this master restoration element, duplication masters, such as composite fine grain masters, are generated to be used to generate additional printing negatives from which actual release prints can be struck for festival screenings and DVD mastering. <!-- (This paragraph is practically commentary, please reword to meet Wikipedia standards or remove altogether.) Another important issue presented is that films of the nineteenth century are deteriorating. Negating internal processes, external factors such as wars and floods could destroy these collections permanently. The argument presented is that if films can be restored and made accessible for public consumption, then active efforts to take advantage of this extraordinary invention should continue. The fact is that at the risk of sounding technology determinist, there will be a solution to the preservation of film and digital format. Cyberspace is developing exponentially one must place it in the context where it is constant to changes in society. For every different medium there has been an exposure of meeting the demands of the audience. If the demands of the audience are to be met then surely a backup of this success is needed and will be sought i.e. an appropriate storage medium. In the next century, film archives may not exist.-->
==Education==
The practice of film preservation is more craft than science. Until the early 1990s there were no dedicated academic programs in film preservation. Practitioners had often entered the field through related education (e.g. library or archival science), related technical experience (e.g. film lab work), or driven by sheer passion for working with film.<ref>Lukow, Gregory. [http://www.amianet.org/sites/all/files/ed_training_careers.pdf "Education Training and Careers in Moving Image Preservation"]. (AMIA, 2000)</ref>
In the last two decades universities globally began offering graduate degrees in film preservation and film archiving, which are often taught conjointly (the latter focusing more on skills related to the description, cataloguing, indexing and broadly speaking management of film and media collections).
The recent years rapid incursion of digital technologies in the field has somewhat redefined the vocational scope of film preservation. In response, the majority of graduate programs in film preservation have begun offering courses on digital film preservation and digital film and media collection management.
Some established graduate programs in the field are: *[http://www.uea.ac.uk/study/postgraduate/taught-degree/detail/ma-film-studies MA in Film Archiving, University of East Anglia] *[http://selznickschool.eastmanhouse.org/certificate_about.html Film Preservation Certificate, Selznick School of Film Preservation] *[http://selznickschool.eastmanhouse.org/masters_about.html MA in Film and Media Preservation, Selznick School of Film Preservation] offered jointly with [[University of Rochester]] *[http://www.nyu.edu/tisch/preservation/ MA in Moving Image Archiving and Preservation, New York University, Tisch School of the Arts] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20131001025147/http://gsh.uva.nl/ma-programmes/programmes/content14/preservation-presentation-of-the-moving-image.html MA in Heritage Studies: Preservation and Presentation of the Moving Image, University of Amsterdam] *[http://www.csu.edu.au/courses/postgraduate/audiovisual_archiving_gc/course-overview Graduate Certificate in Audiovisual Archiving, Charles Sturt University, Australia] *[http://mias.gseis.ucla.edu/ Moving Image Archive Studies, UCLA] *[http://www.ryerson.ca/content/dam/graduate/ppcm/documents/MAFilmPresStreamAd.pdf MA in Film Preservation, Ryerson University, Canada] offered since 2013 as specialization in the graduate program of Photographic Preservation and Collection Management

Bhd.]] | language = English | firstdate = October 1974<ref name="Info The Star"/> | finaldate= 1-16 December 2013 | country = [[Malaysia]] | website = [http://galaxieblog.com.my/ Galaxie Blog] | issn = }} '''''Galaxie''''' was a fortnightly entertainment magazine in Malaysia and published by [[The Star (Malaysia)|Star Publications (M) Sdn. Bhd.]]. The magazine has been published from October 1974 to December 2013.<ref name="Info The Star">{{cite web|title=The Star Online:About The Star|url=http://thestar.com.my/info/thestar.asp|work=The Star|accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref> It is also available in neighboring country, [[Singapore]]. The magazine bows out after 39 years. The last issue was the 1-16 Dec (2013) issue and features [[Elton John]], [[Michael Jackson]], [[Mariah Carey]] and [[Eminem]]; which represent each decade of entertainment.<ref name="The last hurrah"/>
== Awards and Recognitions == Galaxie has been named Entertainment Magazine Of The Year by trade magazine Advertising + Marketing in 2011, 2012 and 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2011%2F4%2F21%2Fnation%2F8520854&sec=nation |title=Galaxie is entertainment mag of the year |publisher=The Star |accessdate=21 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121017184213/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2011%2F4%2F21%2Fnation%2F8520854&sec=nation |archivedate=17 October 2012 |df= }}</ref>

'''Ripley Guinness Rishi''' (formerly Har Parkash, born {{bda|1942|7|7}}, India) holds a number of world records. He is most renowned for having over 200 world flags tattooed on his body, including 49 flags on his face and head. He also has 'Ripley's Believe It or Not' tattooed on his forehead and a map of the world on his abdomen.<ref>[[Ripley's Believe It or Not Annual|Ripley's Believe It or Not! Enter If You Dare]] (2011) p. 154</ref>
== Record attempts == * '''Longest pizza delivery''' - 10,286 miles from Delhi to California to deliver a pizza to the [[Ripley's Believe it or Not|Ripley's Believe It or Not]] museum in San Francisco.<ref name=rishi>http://www.recordholders.org/en/records/rishi.html</ref> * '''Oldest adopted person''' - In 2001 Guinness Rishi adopted his brother-in-law Ravinder Kumar Vig, who became the oldest adopted person at 61 years old.<ref name=rishi /> * '''Ketchup drinking''' - Drinking a bottle of ketchup in less than 40 seconds.<ref>[[Ripley's Believe It or Not Annual|Ripley's Believe It or Not! Seeing is Believing]] (2010) p. 133</ref> * '''Tallest sugar cube tower''' - 64 inches high.<ref>https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/howaboutthat/5966142/Man-to-get-tattoos-of-every-national-flag-on-his-body.html</ref>
== Trivia == Had all of his teeth removed for an attempt to fit 755 drinking straws into his mouth.<ref>http://news.uk.msn.com/odd-news/photos/photos.aspx?cp-documentid=154282833&page=7</ref>

'''The Happy Puzzle Company''' is a retailer and manufacturer of "family puzzles and games",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.happypuzzle.co.uk|title=Fun and Educational Puzzles, Games and Brain Teasers - The Happy Puzzle Company|website=www.happypuzzle.co.uk}}</ref> with "300 award-winning puzzles, games, challenges and puzzle books".<ref name="about">{{cite web|url=https://www.happypuzzle.co.uk/about-us.aspx|title=Puzzles, Games and Brain Teasers - The Happy Puzzle Company|website=www.happypuzzle.co.uk}}</ref> The company is based in [[Elstree]], [[Hertfordshire]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.happypuzzle.co.uk/Other-Information/contact-us.aspx|title=Puzzles, Games and Brain Teasers - The Happy Puzzle Company|website=www.happypuzzle.co.uk}}</ref>
The company sells its products to the general public, supplies its own products to retailers and offers events. In an article in ''[[TES (magazine)|Times Education Supplement]]'', The Happy Puzzle Company's school puzzle challenge days were described as "developing independent learning skills".<ref>"Unlocking Potential", Yolanda Brooks, [[Times Educational Supplement]], Teacher magazine, 18 June 2004</ref> The company offers a service aimed at working with children with dyslexia, dyspraxia and those who are gifted and talented, as well as offering programmes for businesses and charities.<ref name="about"/><ref>"Ideal solution to life's puzzles", [[The Daily Express]], 31 May, 1993</ref>
Founded in 1992, the company won an award for Business of the Year in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.borehamwoodtimes.co.uk/news/5049203.Puzzle_company_wins_business_of_the_year_award/|title=Puzzle company wins business of the year award|website=Borehamwood Times}}</ref> One of the company's products, "The Brain Train", won a 2018 Family Choice Award in the USA.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.familychoiceawards.com/family-choice-awards-winners/children/|title=Children|publisher=Family Choice Award}}</ref>
Jigsaw specialist company, mad4jigsaws is a part of The Happy Puzzle Company.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mad4jigsaws.co.uk|title=Mad4Jigsaws|website=www.mad4jigsaws.co.uk}}</ref>
